did.abstract: Engineers working at ARMA Corporation, a Brooklyn defense contractor, organized the Engineers Association of ARMA in 1951, becoming the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers Local 418 in 1956. After twenty years without a defense contract, the company finally closed in 1983, forcing the union to disband. The collection contains images of union presidents, classroom scenes, women members, and a strike scene.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Apparently separated from the Engineers Association of ARMA Records (Wagner 23).

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Engineers working at ARMA Corporation, a Brooklyn defense contractor, organized the Engineers Association of ARMA in 1951. Company Recruitment of new engineers during the Korean War with a pay rate comparable to senior employees was the central organizing issue. Two strikes, in 1951 and then in 1953, drove the engineers to consolidate their numbers with the other unions in the plant. In 1956, the ARMA engineers formed Local 418 of the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers. The union's survival depended greatly on the ability of the company to secure Pentagon contracts. After twenty years without a defense contract, the company finally closed in 1983, forcing the union to disband.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The 42 photographs in this collection are primarily copy prints. Besides portraits of early presidents from 1951-1960, there are group portraits and classroom scenes (it is unknown what the classes were), as well as one undated strike scene, probably from the 1950s. In addition there is a collection of snapshots of women members, possibly dating from the 1950s when female technicians were admitted as members.
